Message.Title: Nemesis, do you expect EPS > $110 in 2012?
Message.Msg: Trying to figure out the bull case here. If you're buying Amazon at $235 and your cost of capital is 20% per year (very conservative, since anybody who invests in Amazon is probably looking for much more than that), what kind of long-term EPS growth is this implying? Well, if the assumptions above are correct, buyers today expect the stock to be at $1455 in 10 years (2012). Assuming a P/E of 13, EPS would have to be around $110 to justify that valuation. That implies a growth rate of 65% per year of EPS. Considering Amazon's margins have little room for expansion, sales would have to grow at a minimum of 40% for that to happen and I don't believe that's realistic in anyway. What's your take Nem? Where do you see sales growth over the next decade?

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: "AMZN doesn't have to worry about these issues since it has no margins or profits to speak of." Most companies don't (temporarily) when the in the midst of an investment cycle of this scale. The people who need to "worry" would be the investors in those other companies who did not invest in them on the premise of their suffering a short-term decline in earnings. Different types of investors. Probably a lot of retirees who thought that BBY and Target would pay them a steady but tiny dividend each quarter and not go off vaporizing all that cash instead trying start up a useless (to them) price war that they are just going to lose anyway, simply because one or two shorts here thought it was such a bright idea.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: "Huh? The market cap is based on what Amazon will make over its entire existence not a few years." Here, I'll even help you out dummy. Let's say you invested 100 billion into a CD. If that CD paid 1%, you would have 101billion at the end of the year. Now, you can take the "dividend" and keep the 1 billion and reinvest the 100bil next year. Or you can roll your profits into the CD, and now you have 101 bil invested next year. So, if your choice was to buy AMZN for $100bil (because even if you buy 1 share, that is what you are doing), or buy a CD for $100bil, the CD would have far greater returns.

Topic.Title: cramer likes this stock, 260 1 yr target,

Message.Msg: Becareful --- never trust analysts that may be touting a stock while their best institional clients are told to unload the shares. Remember: Jeff Vinick --- 10 years ago or so caught doing exactly this and he's not the Lone Ranger. AMGN is way overbought at $234/sh. No question about it. NFLX at $294/sh was given a glowing call by Cramer when he said that Elaine Chang's $330/sh target was 'too low and my target is $350/sh". NFLX moved to $304/sh and THEN DROPPED $175/sh. So, be careful --- Cramer can be Toxic on momentum stocks.

Message.Title: Valuation...
Message.Msg: PE of 285, ... Have we learned nothing over the last decade? If you apply a market multiple of 15 to current earnings, AMZN is worth about 6B. Add back the cash and it's worth 11B. About a 90% drop. If earnings double, it's worth about 15B - a 70% drop. If the margins double and the earnings double, perhaps its worth 35B - a 66% drop. Hmmmm....

Message.Title: Treasury Note or Amazon Stock??
Message.Msg: Just think - If you take $106B today and buy 10 year treasury notes at the current yield of 1.66% you will earn $1.76B per year in cash vitrually risk free - your biggest risk is interest rate risk given the historically low rates right now. Maybe we should take $106B and buy common stock paper with Amazon printed on it? Is there risk to principle? Yes lots - stock has incurred massive swings up to 90% drops What about the cash? There is none - no dividend and none in sight The stock will continue to appreciate right? No - look at some of the so called greatest stocks in the market like MSFT - the stock has declined significanly since the peak and they are just now paying a dividend. Maybe because Amazon is not at its full earning potential so that's a good reason right? Even if they have this wonderful margin expansion and earn the best margin they ever have enjoyed as a company - 3.67% - You still get the equivelent of granny's CD - but at least granny is collecting the cash where with amazon stock you get nothing! Wow that lousy Tbill is looking like a steal at 1.66
